title: Sterling strongest in 7-1/2-years vs euro on UK rate rise bets
text:
+2.6000 
By Jemima Kelly 
LONDON, July 16 (Reuters) - Sterling strengthened to below 70 pence per euro on Thursday, its strongest level in 7-1/2-years, as traders bet the Bank of England will raise interest rates early next year while monetary policy remains ultra-loose in the euro zone. 
The shared currency was weaker across the board after the Greek parliament approved the austerity plan demanded by its creditors, allowing investors to refocus on the diverging policy outlook for the European Central Bank and its peers in the UK and United States. 
That outlook was crystalised this week, with Bank of England Governor Mark Carney saying a first rise in interest rates since the 2008 financial crash was "moving closer", and U.S. Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen reiterating that a rate hike was on the cards this year. 
Carney, who also played down the impact of a strengthening pound on inflation, helped pull money-market pricing for a UK hike in to the first quarter of next year. Such a move had not previously been expected until May or later. 
Sterling was 0.1 percent lower on Thursday against a dollar boosted by Yellen's comments at $1.5622. Against the euro, the pound was 0.2 percent up at 69.795 pence, having earlier hit 69.695 pence, its strongest since November 2007. 
"The market is starting to turn back to fundamentals as the situation in Greece stabilises, and to the dichotomy in views between the ECB and the BoE," said Nikolaos Sgouropoulos, a G10 currency strategist at Barclays (LSE: BARC.L - news ) in London. 
The pound's gains against the euro helped it reach its strongest since March 2008 against the BoE's trade-weighted basket of currencies, at 94.1. 
Carney's comments earlier in the week followed an uncharacteristically hawkish message from the BoE's monetary policy committee (MPC (KOSDAQ: 050540.KQ - news ) ) member David Miles, who said the idea the BoE had to wait for the Fed to raise rates was "daft". 
But some strategists reckon that whatever is said in public, the BoE will not risk tightening policy, and potentially stifling growth, before U.S. rates have started to increase. 
"If the market firms up expectations of a 2015 Fed lift-off, it can also bring forward expectations of the first UK MPC hike," wrote Societe Generale (Paris: FR0000130809 - news ) strategists in a research note. 
"MPC members are sending a clear message that the time for hikes is approaching and there's less in the UK rate curve than the U.S. one."
